div3.p: --The following prices were obtained yesterday at auction by the Inspectors of Shockoe Warehouse, for part of the crop of Col. W. W. Hancock, of Chesterfield: Two hhds. at $31 per cwt; two do. at $30; one do at $26; one do. lugs at $17,50; one do, do at $16, to D. Von Groning, and one hhd, to E. S. Turpin for $23 per cwt. A good lot of the weed is raised in Chesterfield county, most of which is of fine quality.

div3.head: Died of his wounds.
div3.p: --A man named Brocketts Mack, of La., who was shot in a fracas in Henrico county, a few days since, died yesterday of his wounds.

div3.head: Flag of Trues Delayed.
div3.p: --The Yankee prisoners did not start for Varina yesterday as contemplated, on account of the inclemency of the weather.--They will be sent off to-day if the weather should prove favorable to the undertaking.

div3.head: Proceedings in the Courts.
div3.p:
--Patrick, slave of Andrew Antoni, was brought up for trial, for having, on Thursday night, about 10 o'clock, been caught by the watch with ten pounds of candy, sugar, almonds, &c., in his possession, with which he was making an attempt to reach Exchange Alley.
The property belonged to his master.
Twenty lashes were awarded in this case Fifteen stripes were ordered to be administered to Robert, slave of J. R. Anderson, for stealing wood from off the Basin bank, Thursday morning, about 4 o'clock.

The case of E. Hunter Taliaferro, charged with forging sundry checks and Treasury warrants of the State of Virginia for the payment of $14,000, was called, and continued until Thursday next, on account of the absence of important witnesses.--Prisoner was admitted to ball in the sum of $2,000 for his appearance, J. M. Taliaferro and G. J. Seammell becoming bound as his sureties.

Alexander Askew, hailing from Hanover, was arraigned for lying on the sidewalk of Main street Thursday night, and encumbering the thoroughfare.
The Mayor said he must pay a fine of $1--Askew, confessing his utter impecuniosity on the occasion, was relieved from his embarrassment by several charitable persons present, who subscribed the necessary amount, and let him go on his way rejoicing.

John Lowell, a mulatto, was arraigned for impudence to Thomas Feltner, baker, and Thomas Addison, watchman.
of the Spotswood House.--Lowell represented himself as servant to Colonel Casey, of Kentucky.
Feltner proved that Lowell tried to occupy his bed Thursday night, and when the watchman was called he turned off the gas, ran in a room, barred the door and continued his abuse He was ordered twenty lashed, and committed for inquiry into his status.

The watchmen on Thursday night made a descent on a house in Locust alley, between Main and Franklin sts., kept by Bell Jones, in search of persons having "no visible means of support," and there fore vagrants and candidates for the chain-gang.--The watchmen, during the raid, captured Belle Jones.
Madame du Maison, Laura Bella Roane, Mary Ann Godfrey, Emeline Rodgers, and Kate Mills, and their visitors, young men of various degrees of good and bad looks, giving the names of Wm B Freeman, J. J. Nicholas John Manning, Thos Carroll, Daniel Carroll, Thos. Murphy, Daniel Ryan, Benjamin G Page, B. M. Bear, and Jas. W. Finch.
All were committed in default of security for their good behavior.

Circuit Court of Chester field County, Monday, Nov. 6th.--Present: Hon. Thomas S. Gholson, Judge.
Edward Sears was set to the bar at the Court House in Manchester to day, for trial on the charge of murdering his wife by poison, administered several months since.
The evidence being given in, and the argument of counsel heard, the case was given to the jury, who, after a brief retirement, returned into Court, and reported through their foreman that they had agreed upon a verdict finding the prisoner guilty of murder in the second degree, and ascertaining his term of imprisonment at 18 years in the Penitentiary.
Sentence was passed by the Judge in accordance with the above finding.
J. B Ferguson was then arraigned for the murder, seven months since, of John Jewett, engineer of the Coalfield Railroad, by shooting him to death with a shot-gun while standing on his engine.

Recorder's Court.--Simon, slave of Mrs Matilda F. Denny, was brought before Recorder James K. Caskie, yesterday, at the City Hall, to undergo examination on the charge of having, on the 1st of November, on Byrd street, dangerously wounded Mary Haley and Margaret Keneday, two children, aged respectively nine years, by discharging at them the contents of a loaded gun. The examination was heard before the Recorder because first brought before him in the absence of the Mayor.--The two girls were not present, the wounds received by them precluding any such idea, both being badly injured.
The case was continued until Monday.
Simon did not look like a vicious d key, and it is said that the evidence will establish the fact that he was only "fooling," and had no intention to commit an offence when he discharged the gun in the direction he did.

Called Courts.--A special session of the Hustings Court will convene to-day, at 11 o'clock, at the City Hall, to examine severally into the cases of Wm. E. Jones, charged with killing H. Snow on Broad street last Sunday; Francis Fawley, for robbing J. B. Randall, a paroled soldier, of $19.30, on the 2d of November, at one of the hospitals, and James Jones, for stealing a trunk and contents belonging to Capt. J. G. Hawthorn, near the Danville Depot, one night last week.

div4.p: In this city, on Thursday, the 6th inst., at the residence of the bride's father, by the Rev. Dr. Burrews, Mr. John Freeman to Miss Henry Ellar, eldest daughter of Thomas Wheeley, of this city.
On the evening of the 6th instant, by Rev. Jas R. Gates, Mr. John S. Dethel and Miss Mary C. Going, all of Henrico.
In Sidney, on the 7th instant, Jefferson Davis, youngest child of Richard and Elizabeth Morien, aged 1 year and 5 months.

lg.l: We loved our little Davis dear,
And would have wished him stay,
But let our Father's will be done,
He shines in endless day.
Weep not for me, my parents dear;
I have gone to rest, you need not fear--
My stay was short, as you may see,
Therefore prepare to follow me.

div4.p: The funeral will take place this day (Saturday) at 11 o'clock, from the residence of his parents, on the Westhem plankroad. *
On Thursday evening, at Bendover, the residence of her father, in Goochland county, Ida Henningham Stanard, in the 8th year of her age, only daughter of William B. and Josephine L. Stanard.

Her funeral will take place from St. James' Church at 12 o'clock to-day.
The friends of the family are requested to attend without further notice. *
On the 6th inst., Sarah Hill, daughter of Joseph G. and Mary Jane Hill, aged three years and six months.
Her funeral will take place from her father's residence, to-day, at 2 o'clock P. M. The relatives, friends, and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

div4.head: Funeral Notices.
div4.p: The funeral of Capt. Jos. F. Price, of Hanover, will take place from the Second Baptist Church, (Dr. Seeley's,) corner of Main and 6th streets, at noon to-day, the 8th inst. His friends and the friends of his son, Thomas R. Price, and son-in-law, George E. Danney, are invited to attend.

The funeral of W. W. Newman, of the Parcel battery, killed in an artillery duel on the Rappahannock immediately prior to the second battle of Manassas, will be preached in Sycamore Church on Sunday, (to morrow,) the 9th inst, at 11 o'clock A. M. *

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p:
Died, on the 6th day of November, 1862, in the county of Hanover, Va., at the residence of his son-in-law, Dr. Lucien B. Price, Capt. Joseph Ferrell Price.
He was born in the same county, on the 29th day of March, 1779--one of the gloomiest periods of the Revolution, as his mother often mentioned — and was the son of Capt. Thos. Price, who, like his son, lived to a good old age, and died in the same neighborhood.

The son was educated at the best schools of his day — those of the Rev. Peter Nelson and the Rev John D. Blair, the latter of whom he at one time assisted in teaching, and was afterwards at William and Mary College.

When just 21, on the 2d day of June, 1862, he married Elaina Ferrell Winston, distinguished for beauty, intelligence, and piety, and for the efficient energy with which she aided him in rearing their numerous offspring.
He resided in Hanover until about 1817, discharging, with excellent sense and strict fidelity, the duties of Sheriff and Magistrate, and commanding, to the satisfaction of his fellow citizens, one of the best companies which went into service in the war of 1812.
He then removed to Richmond, where he preceded Dr. Adams as Presiding Magistrate of the city, now called Mayor, and performed his duties with judgment, energy, impartiality, and success.
He acted with Dr. Foushee in laying out Shockoe Hill Cemetery, which death has since filled so rapidly as to require a great enlargement of its limits.
About 1826 he left Richmond, and went to the upper part of Hanover, near Beaver Dam Depot, where he remained upon his farm until 1851.
Being then seventy-two years of age, he imitated the example of his father, in dividing among his children all his property except just enough for the maintenance of himself and wife.
Less than two years afterwards he followed her to the grave.
"By reason of strength" he survived her more than nine years, and, until about two or three years since, retained in a remarkable degree his faculties of body and mind, especially the recollection of recent events, which the old always lose first, and often completely.
He then had an attack of paralysis, which was the signal of a gradual decay in his bodily organs, his spirits, and his intellect.
Although he had been a Federalist and an ardent admirer of Chief Justice Marshall, and clung with an old man's fondness to the Union of our fathers, his last visit to the court house of his native county was to record his vote for the accession of Virginia.
He seemed to think that the gloom which hung over the time of his birth had again gathered around his departing hours.
His son-in-law's residence was for some weeks in the lines of the enemy, who showed their character by not sparing the sanctity of his sick chamber, and stealing the old-fashioned watch which he had worn for fifty years.

Although nursed and soothed by his daughter and her husband with the most exemplary and unwearied care and tenderness, he gradually yielded to the tedium vitŒ, and was anxious to join those loved ones who had gone before him to the land of eternal rest.
In early manhood, under the ministry of the celebrated Andrew Bronadus, he had made a profession of religion and joined the Baptist Church.
As the scenes of earth were gradually receding, his mind and heart were more and more earnestly fixed on the concerns of eternity.
He humbly trusted in the merits of Christ for pardon and happiness.

His person remained tall, erect and commanding, until a very late period of his life His conversation, although peculiar, was sensible, and marked by accuracy of statement, correctness of sentiment, and entire freedom from censoriousness.
His understanding was good and his heart kind.
His integrity was as strict as his economy.
None, even of his descendants, should mourn that he has gone to the rest for which many, not ripe like him, have been tempted to pray in these troublous times.
The best monument which they can erect to his memory will be an imitation of his virtues, and of the wisdom with which he sought pardon for his sins in the promises of the gospel.
Killed, at the battle of Sharpsburg, Md., September 17th, William T Newell, of Parker's battery, of this city, aged 23 years and 5 months.

Thus are we called upon to chronicle the death of another martyr to the cause of Freedom, an only son of a widowed mother, cut down in the very bloom of manhood, when every prospect for the future seemed bright.
But, alas, how uncertain is life.
Having known him from his childhood, I can truly say that his conduct through life was worthy of imitation, for in him was embodied all that characterizes the generous and noble-hearted man. Being of a kind and happy disposition, he was beloved by all who knew him. His conduct in the battery to which he was attached elicited the highest praise from both officers and men. He would never complain of the hardships of a soldier, always possessing the same liveliness of disposition encouraging to all around him. In battle he was cool and brave.
On the field of Manassas he was spoken of as a brave and fearless soldier, and at Sharpsburg, where he received his fatal wound, while nobly doing his duty, his officers say his bravery was unsurpassed.
We sympathize deeply with the bereaved family for this, their irreparable loss.
But we must bow submissively to the will of our Creator.
Their loss is a severe one, but it is his eternal gain, for his spirit has taken its flight to realms of eternal bliss, where "the wicked cease from troubling and the weary are at rest." [*] Comrade
Died, in Portsmouth, Va., on the 21st Oct., Col. Thomas Brooks, Jr., in the 46th year of his age.

In his death the community has lost one of its most enterprising, useful, and worthy citizens; his devoted wife and affectionate children are deprived of the kindest and best of husbands and fathers.
He occupied many offices of trust, which he filled with fidelity and honor to himself and the community.
He possessed those qualities that ennoble a man and endeared him to all who know him. Of him it may be truly said that in all the relations of life he acted well his part.
Long will his memory be cherished. [*] H.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 23, Number 110, page 3.

div3.head: Affairs in Northern Virginia--repulse of the enemy at Castleman's Ferry.
div3.p:
We have received intelligence of an engagement at Castleman's Ferry, on the Shenandoah river, in Clarke county.
It seems that the enemy, whose main force is believed to have crossed the Potomac into Loudoun county, attempted to throw a large body of troops across the Shenandoah at the point designated, with the supposed intention of moving upon Winchester.
Castleman's Ferry is on the direct read from Leesburg to Winchester, and about seventeen miles from the latter point, and about three miles distant from Salekersville, Loudoun county, which is just at the foot of the Blue Ridge.
A brigade of Gen. A. P. Hill's division guarded the Ferry on the west side of the river, and the Federal forces approached from the eastern or Loudoun side.
When the enemy came within range our pieces were opened on them, and a brisk artillery duel of three-fourths of an hour ensued, which resulted in the complete repulse of the Yankees--Singular to say, not a man on the Confederate side was injured, whilst the enemy's loss is known to have been about forty killed and nearly one hundred wounded. After the enemy retired, a flag of truce was sent in requesting permission to remove their wounded and bury their dead.

On the Upper Potomac all was quiet, the only Yankee force known to be on the south side of the river is the garrison at Harper's Ferry.
Our cavalry continue to picket at Charlestown and the neighborhood of Shepherdstown.

There is a report that a portion of the cavalry of General Stuart attacked a body of the enemy's cavalry in the neighborhood of Warrenton on Wednesday, killing three, wounding some fifteen or sixteen, and taking seven or eight prisoners, several horses, and a considerable number of swords, carbines, and pistols, which the enemy disserted themselves of in their flight.
They were retreating when the assault upon them was made, and such was the spirit with which it was made that utter rout was the consequence.
An officer of the Lee battery, writing from Winchester under date of November 3, says:

q.p:
"We moved up here yesterday for forage, from Clarke county, where we spent one week.
The Yankees are close upon us, having crossed from Loudoun through Snicker's Gap.
We have skirmishing daily by A. P. Hill's forces and the enemy.
We learn a small force of Yankees have moved up to Martinsburg, and incline this way. We are prepared for them."

div3.p:
The information with reference to the enemy's moving up to Martinsburg was incorrect at the date mentioned.
We have advices from that neighborhood to the 5th, at which tine all was quiet.

div3.head: Gen. Echols's command.
div3.p:
We learn that our forces under Gen. Echols, in the Kanawha Valley, have fallen back to the Falls some distance above the town of Charleston.
It is stated that this move of Gen. Echols was made upon the representations of a Yankee spy, who palmed himself off for a Federal officer.
He entered the camp of Gen. Echols and surrendered himself up as a prisoner, stating to the General that a large Federal force was coming up in his rear by way of Nicholas Court-House; and upon the statements of this man Gen. S. was induced to retire from his former position.
It subsequently transpired that this party was a Yankee spy, and was no doubt sent for the object which he so successfully effected.
He is said to have had upon his person quite a number of Confederate bills, which was discovered in time to secure his arrest, and he is now in the hands of the military.

div3.head: Shoes for our soldiers — immediate Action necessary.
div3.p:
We give below an appeal, very brief and to the point, in behalf of our suffering soldiers.
In one corps of our army there are twenty-six hundred men without shoes. This is a terrible fact, and an agent sent down here to procure shoes for them is unable to get them.
Shoes that would be deemed useless in a city would be better than nothing.
Anything is better than marching through snow bars footed. Our correspondent is a Confederate officer, whose position enables him to know the facts given:

opener.salute: To the Editor of the Dispatch:

div4.p: --From undoubted authority there are thousands of our brave soldiers in the Army of the Potomac without shoes. The Quartermaster's Department has not supplied them, and is not able, immediately, to do so. What must be their suffering in this cold snow storm?

Thinking it criminal to keep one pair of shoes out of use under these circumstances, a friend and myself have each determined to send a pair to the Army Depot of the Young Men's Christian Association, on Bank, near 10th street, for the use of the soldiers in the field. Is there not enough of patriotism and self denial in Richmond and its vicinity, to send them 10,000 pair by to morrow night?
Let every true man send what he can immediately, and constitute himself an agent for collecting from others Stockings, under-shirts, gloves, &c., will also be useful.

div3.head: From Maryland.
div3.p:
The Rockingham Register is informed by a gentleman from Allegheny county, Md., that there has been no draft for the Lincoln army in the counties of Washington, Cecil, and Allegheny.
The Yankees are in considerable force at New Creek and Green Spring Depot, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, but west of New Creek there is a very small force, only a provost guard at Oakland where there is a railroad bridge.
Wm. F. Gordon, a prominent lawyer at Cumberland, has been arrested two or three times, but released again.

div3.head: Big prices.
div3.p:
--At the sale of the perishable property of Mrs. Martha Layne's estate, in Bedford county, Va on Tuesday, the biggest kind of prices were obtained for everything offered.
Wheat brought as high as $4.30 per bushel, corn $16 per barrel and hogs on foot $30 per cwt. Country people ought to be able to live at these kind of prices.

div3.head: Handsome Exhibit.
div3.p: --The report of President Barbour, of the Orange and Alexandria railroad, shows that the receipts of the road for the past 12 months were $747,000, the expenses $220,000, showing an excess of receipts over expenditures of $527,000.

div3.head: 35 Negroes for Sale at public auction.
div3.p:
--In pursuance of a decree of the Circuit Court of the county of Henrico, in the suit of Darracott's guardian against Darracott and others, the undersigned will offer for sale, at public auction, to the highest bidder, for cash in current funds, at the late residence of Mr. John Darracott, dead, about one mile from the city of Richmond, on the Brook Turnpike, on the 14th day of the present month, (November,) at 11 o'clock. Thirty-five Negroes, belonging to Mr. Darracott's estate.
Many of these slaves are young and very likely.
Some of them are house servants, and five of them (two women and three men) are, I am informed, good cooks, and being sold for no fault, persons desirous of procuring servants for their own use will have a rare opportunity of doing so.
no 4 Benj. Pollard, Com'r.
Sale conducted by Goddin & Apperson Aucts.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 23, Number 110, page 4.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Co. "B," 25th Va Batt'n,
November 6th, 1862.
div3.p: this is to notify Private J. Vaughn and J. D. Dandridge, who are absent without leave, that unless they report in person, or through the certificate of an Army Surgeon, within four days, they will be advertised and treated as deserters.

div3.head:
General Hospital, no. 1,
Richmond, Nov. 1, 1862.
div3.p: Agents and owners of Servants hired at this hospital will call between the hours of 10 A. M. and 3 P. M., on Monday, the 3d, and draw their hire.
Wanted — Immediately, ten colored Servants, as Nurses, for which $18.50 per month will be paid.
div3.closer:
J. S. Dorset, Hospital Steward.
no 3--3t*

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Wise Mounted guard,
Co. "D" 10th Reg't Va. Cav.,
Charles city C. H., Oct. 30, 1862.
div3.p: Notice.--Every member of this company who is not on duty, or absent with proper authority, falling to report at these headquarters by the 5th of November, will be published as deserters and treated accordingly.
div3.closer:
L. J. Hawley, Capt, Co. "D,"
no 3--d3tcw1t* 10th Reg. Va Cavalry.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Hampden Artillery,
Camp Bunker's Hill, October 24th, 1862.
div3.p:
Notice.--All absentees of the late Thomas Artillery will report without delay to these headquarters, Artillery Corps of 1st Division, Jackson's army.
By order (No. 209) of Gen'l R. E. Lee, the two senior Lieutenants and the enlisted men were transferred to my command, and those who have been furnished with transfers since that order was issued are cautioned against using them, as they are worthless.
Those on sick leave will send certificates of inability from a C. S. Surgeon.
div3.closer:
By order of W. H. Caskie, Capt. H. A.
Prompt attention to the above order required.
no 4--5t*

div3.head:
Headquarters 4th Va. Cavalry,
October 7th, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 11.

All officers and men of the 4th Virginia Cavalry, who are absent from the regiment, and are fit for duty, will report in person at their headquarters without delay.
Those who are unfit for duty will send certificates from Confederate surgeons regularly.
Paroled prisoners from this regiment will send in their names forthwith to Col. Robert Ould, agent for the exchange of prisoners at Richmond, and will thus report at once to their companies.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Wms. C. Wickham,
Commanding 4th Va. Cavalry.
P. Fontaine, Adjutant. oc 13--10t

div3.p:
All members of company D, 21st Virginia regiment, now absent from said company, from any cause whatever, are hereby ordered to report immediately, or if unfit for duty from physical disability, are required to send a Confederate Surgeon's certificate to that effect.
If this order is not promptly complied with all absentees will be considered as deserters and treated as such.
Others than those on furlough, fifteen days are given for the compliance with this order.
div3.closer:
Wm. E. Booker, 2d Lieut.,
no 4--1w* Comd'g said Company.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders
div3.p:
--All Marylanders who wish to join an Infantry Company, just forming, to be called the "Maryland Exiles," composed of young men from the lower counties of Maryland, will please call without delay, at the rendezvous of the Maryland Line, at the Palmetto House, on 12th street, above Main. When the company is full the men will have the privilege of electing their own officers.
Come one!
come all!! your country needs your services.

div3.head: To the Captains of companies in and near Richmond.
div3.p:
--I hereby warn all persons against Patrick McDONOUGH, a British subject.
He is endeavoring to substitute in some company, and I am fully convinced that immediately after substituting and obtaining the substitute money, he will desert.
I have had such experience with him as to justify the above assertion.

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders.
div3.p:
--A Rifle Company, composed of Marylanders, as an independent company, is about being formed.
All who wish to join will call at the office, on Cary st., near 14th.

div3.head: For hire — a house servant and seamstress.
div3.p:
--A superior house servant and seamstress just from the country, for hire for the remainder of the year.
Apply to me at I. H. Wilee's store, Main street.
no 7--ts Ed. M. Morgan.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to hire Cooks, Washers, Ironers, or men, would do well to call on Park Jones, Canal st., between 1st and 2d sts. One of the above is a very good rough carpenter.
no 5--3t*

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A smart, active boy, thirteen year of age, capable of waiting in a dining-room.
Terms: $10 per month.
Apply to
Lieut J. Johns,
no 4--5t* No. 31 Pearl st.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, for no cause whatever, on the 25th October a negro man named Griffin, a dark mulatto, 5 feet 4 or 5 inches high, 35 years old, and stammers when spoken to. Having had his left arm broken when young, it is much smaller than his right, which may be discovered from the peculiar position of the hand and fingers.
Said negro was sold by Dickinson & Hill, on the 6th of last month, for Robert Love of N. C. The above reward will be paid if he is delivered to me at Laurel Grove, in Hanover, two miles from Atlee's station, and all reasonable expenses paid, or lodged in some jail, so that I get him.

Griffin was raised in Norfolk, and has a mother and wife and children there.
No doubt he will attempt to make his way to them, or to Chapel Hill, Orange county, N. C., as he has acquaintances there.
[no 5--10t*] J. Monroe Carter.

div3.head: $300 reward!
div3.p: Left my dwelling, in Richmond, Sunday evening, Oct. 12th, my negro man, Geo. Yates, about 26 years old; yellow complexion; about 5 feet 8 to 10 inches high; a scar on his neck under his jaw, and has a cock or cross-eye.

Also, two negro men left my farm, about two miles out of town, about the same time of day.--One man, Morton, aged about 24 or 25 years; black; about 5 feet 10 inches high; no scars recollected;--and boy Dick; 18 years of age; about 5 feet 6 or 7 inches high black, and had on when he left a deep-blue jacket, with brass buttons, and black glaze cap.

Morton is recently from Culpeper county, Va., and Dick I bought from Fauquier county, near Warrenton, Va., last January.
George was raised by me in Richmond.

I have no doubt but all three are aiming to make their escape to the Yankees by way of Gordonsville and Culpeper.
I will give $160 for each of them, delivered to me in Richmond, or secured in jail so I can get them again.
oc 29--d20t,sw1t,w1t* Silas Omohundro.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward
div3.p: for the following named servants, as follows:

list.item:
1st. $40 for the apprehension and delivery to me of a servant Dr. named Conway, belonging to Dr. Wm. J. Hallel, of Essex county.
Conway left where he was hired, in Rocketts, in June last, and was, when last heard of, with the 2d Florida regiment.
He is about 13 or 14 years old; dark color.
2d. $20 for the delivery of Simeon to me.--Simeon is about 15 years old; is quite black; was hired to Mr. Johnson, in Chesterfield, and belongs to Mrs. R. B. Murphy, in Westmoreland county.

3d. $20 for a bright mulatto boy named William, goes by the name of Ben frequently.
He is about 15 years old; belongs to James.
C. Roy, of Henrico, and was hired at Mrs. Jones's boardinghouse, Broad street; left in March.

4th. $15 for Cornelius, a well-set man; black color; speaks slow when spoken to; has his hair plaited sometimes; he left about the middle of June, has been to his wife's, at Mr. Richard Longest, in King and Queen county, where it is believed he is now. James Moore,

div3.p: oc 29--6t* At Duke & Hutcheson's Richmond.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the 15th of May last, Albert.
He is about 19 years of age, badly grown, not more than 5 feet high, but well made, of light complexion, hair somewhat reddish; some of the front teeth of the lower jaw were kicked out some years ago, which can be readily seen by examining his teeth; the tip end of one of the fore fingers is cut off, (left hand, I think) leaving a very small portion of nail which is thickish and pointed.
He is of a lively manner, and incl ned to be very communicative and forward in manner.
He was seen in Winchester about a week ago. He spoke to a gentleman from Richmond and said he belonged to me, and was there with his young master.
I feel sure he has hired himself to some of the soldiers as a free boy.

Also, about the same time, Sandy.
He is about 32 years old, tall and trim speaks rather slow and broad, and is respectful in manner.
He is an excellent waiting man and driver.
It is likely he is employed in one or the other capacity in the army.
Complexion somewhat light.
He has a wife and children at Mrs. Jeremiah Hobbs's, in Manchester.
I will pay $50 for either of them, delivered to me, near Hampden Sidney College, or lodged in jail so I may get either of them.

oc 29--2aw4w* P. H. Anderson.
M. D.

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber last spring a negro boy, about 15 years of age, named Robert Andrew, of rather bright complexion, very sprightly, and stammers a little when spoken to. I have good reason to believe that he left here with some portion of our Amy, and he is doubtless with them yet. I will give the above reward for his delivery to me, or for information that will lead to his recovery.
Address, John W. Clarke,
oc 16--12t* Box 637, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my farm, on the 16th of October, my negro boy, named Dennis, 23 years of age, bright mulatto, freckled face, about 5 feet 4 inches in height, thick set, and rather grum countenance; had on when he left blue pants, black overcoat, shoes, and black felt hat. He is no doubt making his way to the Federal lines.
The above reward will be paid for his apprehension and delivery to me, or secured in any jail so I may get him.

oc 18--9t* Goochland Court-House.
Va.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my farm, about the 1st of August last, my boy Billy.
He is about 15 years of age, a dark mulatto, of stout build, speaks quickly when spoken to, has a full face, large, black eyes, and a full head of hair.
I will pay the above reward for his arrest and delivery to me, or confined in any jail so that I may get him.
oc 28--6t James M. Taylor.

div3.head: Ran away--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, on the 24th inst., from Hanover Junction, John H. Williams.
He is about 24 years old, five feet three or four inches high, of dark gingerbread color, full face, thick set, and had on when he left a straw hat and brown jeans coat.
Said boy has a bad appearance when spoken to, and claims to be free.
I will pay the above reward of $25 for his delivery to me, at Mrs. Ladd's boarding-house, on Franklin street, between 17th and 18th, or at Robert Lumpkin's Jail.
[oc 25--6t*] Wm. A. Allen.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--A brown-colored servant girl, about 20 years old, named Sylva, rather short and thick set, and of very plausible manners.
A suitable reward will be paid for her return to Bellevue Hospital, corner of Broad and 22d streets, Church Hill.
oc 25--74*

div3.head: Ten dollars reward
div3.p: will be paid for the arrest and delivery to E. Lasard, 49 Main street, of a servant woman, Presilla, 25 years old, dark gingerbread color, the forefinger on the left hand cut off near the first joint.
no 4--6t* J. W. Burton.

div3.head: Twenty-five dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $25 for the apprehension and delivery to me, in Richmond, of my servant woman, Louisa, who absconded from Hanover county in the month of May last.
She is about medium height, bright gingerbread color, speaks rapidly, and is about 40 years of age. [oc 24--2aw4t*] Jas T. Sutton.

div3.head: Was brought to my jail.
div3.p:
--October 9, 1862, a negro man, named Washington.
Says he belongs to Wm. Greentree, of Rockbridge county, Va. Said negro is of a black complexion about twenty-one years old, five feet five inches high, and has lost two of his front teeth.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay expenses, and take him away.
oc 31--7t* Robert Lumpkin.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Richmond, James McCLURE, a free negro, but bought by me for jail fees.
He is about 5 feet 10 inches high, and is a bright mulatto.
He is probably with or near our army on the Potomac.
The above reward will be paid if delivered at Lumpkin's Jail, in this city.
Wm. A. Allen.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward
div3.p:
will be paid for the arrest, and delivery to E. Lasard, 49 Main st., of a servant woman, Priscilla, 25 years old and dark ginger-bread color.
The fore finger on her left hand is cut off near the first joint.
no 1--6t* T. W. Burton,
